Rationale
Background: In 2016 the School of Life Sciences has undergone a review of its assessment strategies which involved student representatives as well as staff from across the School. The outcomes of the review were informed by a large student survey as well as a comprehensive staff consultation which also involved all programme directors and programme teams. The final recommendations were agreed by the School’s Board of Study meeting in January 2017 and aim towards a better consistency in the School’s assessment format and weighting.
This module: The size of the coursework (1500 words) does not justify the original weighting of 30% (according to the new guidelines), therefore it will be reduced to 20%.
No other parts of the University will be affected.

Admin

Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Replace Instances with Code
LIFE339
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2020

Overview

Overview
This module will offer students an understanding of the physiological mechanisms that drive adaptations to challenging environmental conditions, including anoxia, toxic sulfide exposure, high hydrostatic pressure, and extreme temperatures.

It will also examine the physiological processes associated with homeostasis, the evolution of air-breathing, life on land, and endothermy.

Taking an integrative approach, the module will consider physiological mechanisms at various levels, from molecules and cells to tissues, whole organisms, and their environments.

Instruction will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded short online lectures and live online seminars, with assessment conducted through coursework.
Educational Aims
Develop students’ understanding of the physiological mechanisms that underpin animal adaptations to environmental conditions;

Develop students’ ability to solve complex physiological problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will provide students with an insight into physiological mechanisms underpinning adaptations to potentially hostile environmental conditions such as anoxia, toxic sulphide, high hydrostatic pressure and extreme temperatures.

It will also explore the physiological mechanisms related to homeostasis and the evolution of air-breathing, terrestriality and endothermy.

The module will take an integrative approach, considering physiological mechanisms from molecules to cells, tissues, whole animals and the environment.

The module is taught through a mixture of pre-recorded short online lectures and synchronous online seminars and is assessed by coursework.
Outline Syllabus
Life without oxygen:

Anaerobic metabolism;

Buffering;

Metabolic depression;

Diving mammals:

Aerobic diving limits;

Circulatory adjustments;

Decompression sickness.

Thermal challenges:

Freeze avoidance and freeze tolerance;

How membranes and enzymes functions are protected.

Respiratory gases: 

Respiratory gas transport and circulation;

Haemoblobin oxygen transport adaptations;

Counter-current exchangers;

Gas secretion and heat exchange;

Evolution of air breathing and terrestriality;

Evolution of endothermy.  
Teaching and Learning Methods
The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:
Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.
Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE.
Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc and many hours of fieldwork. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Students submit their first group report and receive feedback before they submit their individual report. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.
Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Analysing and reporting scientific data is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. This requires students to lead their enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.
Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.
Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Pre-recorded (asynchronous) short lectures that introduce the key topics
Attendance Recorded: No
Notes: This refers to asynchronous lecture videos (20-30 min each, up to 2 hours per week in total) which students will watch in their own time.

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: These are interactive (synchronous) online sessions. If possible, some of these might be held face to face.
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: courseworkThese weekly sessions will be used for discussions, question and answer sessions, assessment advice and feedback.

Teaching Method 3 – Self-Directed Learning
Description: This includes reading of key articles in preparation for seminars, as well as background reading and preparation of assignments

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two pieces of coursework both of which are in the format of an essay consisting of a critical interpretation of data related to the presented case studies. In these assessments, we expect students to write a well-structured essay which correctly uses the appropriate terminology and referencing. To provide context, students should give background information based on the relevant module content. When they address the question, they should use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. At the higher end of the marking scheme, markers will also be looking for an element of criticality and synthesis. We will also expect a well-founded conclusion.
The first assessment (40%) is scheduled mid semester, and students will receive detailed feedback that they can then apply to the second assessment (60%) which is scheduled at the end of the semester. Prior to the first assessment students will have the opportunity to write a formative piece of the same nature, followed by class feedback.

Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. They require students to apply problem solving skills which are expected by many employers of our graduates.
.

Reassessment strategy: the format of the reassessment will be the same as the original assignment but alternative datasets will be used. These will take place in the normal reassessment window and will be capped at 40%

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

 S3 ​Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.

Rationale
Background: In 2016 the School of Life Sciences has undergone a review of its assessment strategies which involved student representatives as well as staff from across the School. The outcomes of the review were informed by a large student survey as well as a comprehensive staff consultation which also involved all programme directors and programme teams. The final recommendations were agreed by the School’s Board of Study meeting in January 2017 and aim towards a better consistency in the School’s assessment format and weighting.
This module: The size of the coursework (1500 words) does not justify the original weighting of 30% (according to the new guidelines), therefore it will be reduced to 20%.
No other parts of the University will be affected.

Admin

Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Replace Instances with Code
LIFE339
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2020

Overview

Overview
This module will offer students an understanding of the physiological mechanisms that drive adaptations to challenging environmental conditions, including anoxia, toxic sulfide exposure, high hydrostatic pressure, and extreme temperatures.

It will also examine the physiological processes associated with homeostasis, the evolution of air-breathing, life on land, and endothermy.

Taking an integrative approach, the module will consider physiological mechanisms at various levels, from molecules and cells to tissues, whole organisms, and their environments.

Instruction will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded short online lectures and live online seminars, with assessment conducted through coursework.
Educational Aims
Develop students’ understanding of the physiological mechanisms that underpin animal adaptations to environmental conditions;

Develop students’ ability to solve complex physiological problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will provide students with an insight into physiological mechanisms underpinning adaptations to potentially hostile environmental conditions such as anoxia, toxic sulphide, high hydrostatic pressure and extreme temperatures.

It will also explore the physiological mechanisms related to homeostasis and the evolution of air-breathing, terrestriality and endothermy.

The module will take an integrative approach, considering physiological mechanisms from molecules to cells, tissues, whole animals and the environment.

The module is taught through a mixture of pre-recorded short online lectures and synchronous online seminars and is assessed by coursework.
Outline Syllabus
Life without oxygen:

Anaerobic metabolism;

Buffering;

Metabolic depression;

Diving mammals:

Aerobic diving limits;

Circulatory adjustments;

Decompression sickness.

Thermal challenges:

Freeze avoidance and freeze tolerance;

How membranes and enzymes functions are protected.

Respiratory gases: 

Respiratory gas transport and circulation;

Haemoblobin oxygen transport adaptations;

Counter-current exchangers;

Gas secretion and heat exchange;

Evolution of air breathing and terrestriality;

Evolution of endothermy.  
Teaching and Learning Methods
The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:
Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.
Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE.
Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc and many hours of fieldwork. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Students submit their first group report and receive feedback before they submit their individual report. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.
Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Analysing and reporting scientific data is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. This requires students to lead their enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.
Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.
Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Pre-recorded (asynchronous) short lectures that introduce the key topics
Attendance Recorded: No
Notes: This refers to asynchronous lecture videos (20-30 min each, up to 2 hours per week in total) which students will watch in their own time.

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: These are interactive (synchronous) online sessions. If possible, some of these might be held face to face.
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: courseworkThese weekly sessions will be used for discussions, question and answer sessions, assessment advice and feedback.

Teaching Method 3 – Self-Directed Learning
Description: This includes reading of key articles in preparation for seminars, as well as background reading and preparation of assignments

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two pieces of coursework both of which are in the format of an essay consisting of a critical interpretation of data related to the presented case studies. In these assessments, we expect students to write a well-structured essay which correctly uses the appropriate terminology and referencing. To provide context, students should give background information based on the relevant module content. When they address the question, they should use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. At the higher end of the marking scheme, markers will also be looking for an element of criticality and synthesis. We will also expect a well-founded conclusion.
The first assessment (40%) is scheduled mid semester, and students will receive detailed feedback that they can then apply to the second assessment (60%) which is scheduled at the end of the semester. Prior to the first assessment students will have the opportunity to write a formative piece of the same nature, followed by class feedback.

Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. They require students to apply problem solving skills which are expected by many employers of our graduates.
.

Reassessment strategy: the format of the reassessment will be the same as the original assignment but alternative datasets will be used. These will take place in the normal reassessment window and will be capped at 40%

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

 S2 ​Literacy application of literacy, ability to produce clear, structured written work and oral literacy - including listening and questioning
 S3 ​Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.

Rationale
Background: In 2016 the School of Life Sciences has undergone a review of its assessment strategies which involved student representatives as well as staff from across the School. The outcomes of the review were informed by a large student survey as well as a comprehensive staff consultation which also involved all programme directors and programme teams. The final recommendations were agreed by the School’s Board of Study meeting in January 2017 and aim towards a better consistency in the School’s assessment format and weighting.
This module: The size of the coursework (1500 words) does not justify the original weighting of 30% (according to the new guidelines), therefore it will be reduced to 20%.
No other parts of the University will be affected.

Admin

Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Replace Instances with Code
LIFE339
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2020

Overview

Overview
This module will offer students an understanding of the physiological mechanisms that drive adaptations to challenging environmental conditions, including anoxia, toxic sulfide exposure, high hydrostatic pressure, and extreme temperatures.

It will also examine the physiological processes associated with homeostasis, the evolution of air-breathing, life on land, and endothermy.

Taking an integrative approach, the module will consider physiological mechanisms at various levels, from molecules and cells to tissues, whole organisms, and their environments.

Instruction will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded short online lectures and live online seminars, with assessment conducted through coursework.
Educational Aims
Develop students’ understanding of the physiological mechanisms that underpin animal adaptations to environmental conditions;

Develop students’ ability to solve complex physiological problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will provide students with an insight into physiological mechanisms underpinning adaptations to potentially hostile environmental conditions such as anoxia, toxic sulphide, high hydrostatic pressure and extreme temperatures.

It will also explore the physiological mechanisms related to homeostasis and the evolution of air-breathing, terrestriality and endothermy.

The module will take an integrative approach, considering physiological mechanisms from molecules to cells, tissues, whole animals and the environment.

The module is taught through a mixture of pre-recorded short online lectures and synchronous online seminars and is assessed by coursework.
Outline Syllabus
Life without oxygen:

Anaerobic metabolism;

Buffering;

Metabolic depression;

Diving mammals:

Aerobic diving limits;

Circulatory adjustments;

Decompression sickness.

Thermal challenges:

Freeze avoidance and freeze tolerance;

How membranes and enzymes functions are protected.

Respiratory gases: 

Respiratory gas transport and circulation;

Haemoblobin oxygen transport adaptations;

Counter-current exchangers;

Gas secretion and heat exchange;

Evolution of air breathing and terrestriality;

Evolution of endothermy.  
Teaching and Learning Methods
The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:
Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.
Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE.
Active learning: Delivery methods will include discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc and many hours of fieldwork. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence and allow them to work at their own pace. Students submit their first group report and receive feedback before they submit their individual report. Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.
Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Analysing and reporting scientific data is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. This requires students to lead their enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.
Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.
Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Pre-recorded (asynchronous) short lectures that introduce the key topics
Attendance Recorded: No
Notes: This refers to asynchronous lecture videos (20-30 min each, up to 2 hours per week in total) which students will watch in their own time.

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: These are interactive (synchronous) online sessions. If possible, some of these might be held face to face.
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: courseworkThese weekly sessions will be used for discussions, question and answer sessions, assessment advice and feedback.

Teaching Method 3 – Self-Directed Learning
Description: This includes reading of key articles in preparation for seminars, as well as background reading and preparation of assignments

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two pieces of coursework both of which are in the format of an essay consisting of a critical interpretation of data related to the presented case studies. In these assessments, we expect students to write a well-structured essay which correctly uses the appropriate terminology and referencing. To provide context, students should give background information based on the relevant module content. When they address the question, they should use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. At the higher end of the marking scheme, markers will also be looking for an element of criticality and synthesis. We will also expect a well-founded conclusion.
The first assessment (40%) is scheduled mid semester, and students will receive detailed feedback that they can then apply to the second assessment (60%) which is scheduled at the end of the semester. Prior to the first assessment students will have the opportunity to write a formative piece of the same nature, followed by class feedback.

Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. They require students to apply problem solving skills which are expected by many employers of our graduates.
.

Reassessment strategy: the format of the reassessment will be the same as the original assignment but alternative datasets will be used. These will take place in the normal reassessment window and will be capped at 40%

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
